{"blocks":[{"key":"49utn","text":"There are a number of ways to purify His-tagged proteins. I opted for the HisPur Cobalt resin for a few reasons. Resins are available in agarose bead and magnetic bead format - magnetic beads are attractive for high throughput and automated protocols, but their binding capacities are 100-1000fold lower per volume than agarose resins. While I don’t need grams of protein, I did require ug-mg yields, so it had to be agarose. The most popular resin is the Nickel resin (NiNTA) but I opted for Cobalt because, while its capacity is lower this is not a problem at the scales I require, but its specificity is higher ensuring purer protein.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bnhua","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"874ds","text":"Back of the envelope calculation to illustrate:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5oleb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3r1i5","text":"HisPur Cobalt resin. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":19}],"data":{}},{"key":"92ubk","text":"    Capacity of the resin: 10mg/ml (lower than NiNTA but higher specificity).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"35h4a","text":"spin columns ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbslf","text":"    I use Pierce Spin Columns - Snap Cap. The standard/smallest one has a max volume of 300ul 50% resin, which means a total yield of 3mg protein can be obtained from Cobalt resins, or 20mg protein max from NiNTA. This is typically sufficient: assuming all protein ends up in one quant assay, we’re talking a starting conc for the highest conc in the plate would be (E1 neat: 3mg/100ul = 3000ug/100ul = 30ug/ul; E1/10 =) 3ug/ul. If I get a conc of 500ng/ul here I’m happy (6x less). Minimum is probably 100ng/ul (30x less).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":10,"length":30}],"data":{}},{"key":"781a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1jja","text":"Nickel and Cobalt resins tolerate most common reagents except EDTA (so there’s no EDTA in the lysis buffer). DTT is disputed - manual for HisPur says to avoid it completely. DTT use (1mM) was tested and found to make not much difference to purification yields. Meaning DTT 1mM shouldn’t negatively affect the columns. Subsequently however I didn’t use it because it interferes w microBCA assays, and FPs seem happy enough without (but many of them only have a single Cys anyway).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56l9j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38jel","text":"[ {"blocks":[{"key":"aotdv","text":"[ Day 3 ]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fin5m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20ou8","text":"I do a buffer exchange every time (to T5N15-+pi) because it is essential for microBCA and A280 assay accuracy. However, if only ECmax assays are going to be done, technically this step is optional. T5N15 + pi should be made fresh. There is no data on pi stability so in practise I never use >1day old buffer. Filter sterilise to get rid of cloudy precipitate (doesn’t disappear even when dissolved at 37oC. According to the manual, this is normal, but it may interfere with assays.)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":482}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3j9bg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f57kp","text":"Minimum concentrations for FP elutions in the next steps are > 100 ng/ul, as the highest conc to be measured in will be Elution/10, and 10 ng/ul is still within range of the protein assays. It usually makes sense to merge all elutions before starting.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8okc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3nog5","text":"Notes before starting:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eastn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"984bh","text":"As E1>>E2>>E3, combining all three and concentrating back to the original volume of E1, 300ul, is unlikely to make a big difference in the conc of E1 pre-concentration to conc of E123 post-concentration. However, it should increase. But if this is further concentrated to 100ul then at least a 3X increase in concentration should result.
","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ul53","text":"Amicons claim 100 mM imidazole is the maximum compatibility of the columns. The elutions contain 150 mM. So technically the first step should be to DILUTE the elution 2-fold, but in practice it works fine as is.
","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b6sju","text":"Amicons are not compatible with >0.1% Triton X100 and Triton can interfere w A280 absorbance in protein assays. If sonication was used, no problem. If Triton was used, typically this means there’s 0.1% in the lysis buffer. If the bound resin was washed with 10 column volumes of Triton-free buffer, perhaps Triton shouldn’t be an issue, but this hasn’t been tested.
","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a10p6","text":"Amicon concentration can be taken as an opportunity for buffer exchange, eg. dilute out imidazole and protease inhibitors and buffer exchange from T50N300 to T5N15. But obviously to compare different proteins they should be treated the same. Note: for the experiments in the paper, I (i) merged and concentrated E1+E2+E3 (900ul) to 50ul, (ii) buffer exchanged (3x450ul) into T5N15 and made up to 100ul, (iii) split the FPs into 2x50ul and buffer exchanged (3x450ul) either into T5N15 again, or T5N15+pi. Step (ii) was required to remove imidazole, and step (iii) to add pi back to one half of the sample, because I wanted to compare T5N15 and T5N15+pi in the following assays. In practise, it makes sense to do only one buffer exchange, straight into your buffer of choice.
","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ep42v","text":"Steps:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"84kvi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5a6nj","text":"Situation: E1 is estimated at 100ng/ul","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2dh9g","text":"Plan: ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4i2ai","text":"    1) merge E1, E2, E3 (=300x3 = 900ul) and concentrate to 50ul","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fmj8q","text":"    2) buffer exchange and concentrate to < 100ul","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31frf","text":"    3) resuspend to 100-300ul","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jh20","text":"Use Amicon Ultra 10K columns","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vu33","text":"    500ul capacity (500ul -> 15ul possible)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aeitu","text":"    spin at 14Kg 10’ to concentrate","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b4g09","text":"    spin at 1Kg 1’ to recover","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9pi0d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dl4ff","text":"Step1. {"blocks":[{"key":"4cfv1","text":"The idea behind this protocol is to make most efficient use of protein. Therefore, ideally, one 100ul aliquot of the merged/concentrated Elution (E123), is all that is needed for all the fluorescence and concentration assays, and these can be done consecutively on a single dilution series. Currently an ‘exhaustive’ workflow includes 1 fluorescence assay and 3 protein assays. As this is the 'short' protocol, this only uses 1 fluorescence assay and 1 protein assay - the ECmax assay.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e8jc2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5tuug","text":"Summary:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1hv50","text":"You will need 100ul elution of each FP to be calibrated.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16lgq","text":"Access to all plate readers to be calibrated for a clear few hours is ideal, but the time required depends entirely on ambition: the number of instruments, channels and FPs.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fitm","text":"Prep dilutions as 200ul in the same type of plate as you use for bacterial assays -\u003e absorbance scans and fluorescence quants.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2srs5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"biufd","text":"There is only one protein concentration assay ('protein assay') in this simplified workflow - the ECmax assay.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":72,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75tp1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48aie","text":"Therefore plates to scan in order are:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"almdt","text":"200ul clear - ECmax assay/fluorescence assay","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gfv5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pdqt","text":"–","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cp97","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"csauv","text":"[ Day 3 contd ]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6uc2p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"51o6u","text":"Prepare dilutions of FPs. Run scans in plate reader for FP quantification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"60nbf","text":"1. Make Protein Dilutions in Eppies","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5u2d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9j6i","text":"In order to validate the protein quantitation assays, I dilute each FP using serial dilutions and measure the concentration and fluorescence of each. In order to maximise both the dilution series and the number of FPs quantifiable per plate, I typically arrange FPs in 96-well plates in pairs of rows (AB, CD, EF, GH) - each FP is therefore measured as a duplicate. This leaves the columns for the dilution series itself, with 11 used for protein dilutions, and one for the buffer. (NB: In theory, arranging FPs in columns, with 7 dilutions plus one buffer for each FP, would allow for 6 proteins to be measured at the same time.)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ei8nt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"j77g","text":"I recommend preparing dilution series in 1.5ml eppies: they are easier to handle (and see into) than wells of a deep well plate, important for avoiding {"blocks":[{"key":"6p87j","text":"The aim of this protocol is that for a given FP, we can relate the number of FP molecules to the 'relative' fluorescence units observed in a given instrument, with a given filter set, and gain. The previous steps described how to purify FPs to produce calibrants and how to run the assays. The output data from such assays must now be analysed to obtain calibrations. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8dpeh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6sgir","text":"To assist with this process, we have developed an R package called FPCountR. The full details are on the GitHub page. In brief, functions in this package are provided for each analytical step. parser() functions parse plate reader data into idealised formats. get_concentration() functions calculate protein concentration from absorbance data. The generate_cfs() function obtains conversion factors using concentration and fluorescence data. Finally, process_plate() and calc_percell() functions extract data from microbial growth curves in units of molecules, and molecules/cell.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
